source_methodology: Evidence-based protocols from rehabilitation and sports medicine textbooks
clinical_evidence_level: Grade A and B recommendations from peer-reviewed research

source_books: Ultimate Back Fitness and Performance (6th Ed.)
protocols.author: Stuart McGill
protocols.clinical_evidence: 30+ years spine biomechanics research, 240+ peer-reviewed publications
protocols.prevalence: 80% of population experiences low back pain, 23% have chronic symptoms

exercises_to_avoid.reason: Create 8000+ Newtons spine compression vs 3000N safety threshold
exercises_to_avoid.research: McGill (2007): Spine loading during common exercises

exercises_to_avoid.reason: Combined flexion and rotation increases disc injury risk 5-fold
exercises_to_avoid.research: Callaghan & McGill (2001): Intervertebral disc herniation studies

exercises_to_avoid.reason: Excessive extension increases facet joint compression by 300%

exercise_substitutions.rationale: Reduces spine compression from 8000N to <3000N while maintaining 45-55% rectus activation
exercise_substitutions.research: Vera-Garcia et al. (2000): EMG analysis of abdominal exercises

exercise_substitutions.rationale: Builds posterior chain endurance without excessive spine loading
exercise_substitutions.research: McGill et al. (1999): Spine stability exercise analysis

phase_3_return_to_function.discharge_criteria: Full function without pain for 1 month

warning_signs: Radiating pain below knee (possible nerve involvement)
Loss of bowel/bladder control (cauda equina syndrome)

objective_measures: McGill endurance test ratios within normal limits
functional_tests: Can perform McGill Big 3 without symptoms
Return to work duties without modification

research_outcomes.success_rate: 76% reduction in recurrence using McGill Method

source_books: Rehabilitation Techniques for Sports Medicine (7th Ed.)
protocols.author: William Prentice
protocols.clinical_evidence: NATA Hall of Fame, 40+ years clinical experience

exercises_to_avoid.reason: Patellofemoral contact pressure increases 7.6-fold at deep angles
Creates anterior shear forces 3000% greater than functional activities
exercises_to_avoid.research: Wilk et al. (1996): Patellofemoral rehabilitation guidelines

exercises_to_avoid.reason: Downhill running increases patellofemoral stress by 45%

exercise_substitutions.rationale: Maintains quadriceps activation while limiting patellofemoral stress to safe ranges
exercise_substitutions.research: Escamilla et al. (1998): Knee biomechanics during squatting

exercise_substitutions.rationale: Isolates quadriceps without patellofemoral compression forces
Reduces impact forces while maintaining functional strengthening
exercise_substitutions.research: Wilk & Reinold (2001): Principles of patellofemoral rehabilitation

phase_2_strengthening.progression: Increase hold time before adding resistance

biomechanical_factors: Hip weakness contributes to 75% of anterior knee pain cases
Foot pronation increases knee valgus stress by 25%
prevention_strategies: Hip strengthening reduces injury risk by 45% (Powers, 2010)
Quadriceps flexibility programs decrease symptoms in 70% of cases
Proper footwear reduces impact forces by 15-25%

source_books: Rehabilitation Techniques for Sports Medicine (7th Ed.)
protocols.clinical_evidence: Most common shoulder disorder, 44-65% of shoulder pain cases

exercises_to_avoid.reason: Places shoulder in extreme external rotation increasing impingement risk 300%
exercises_to_avoid.research: Gross et al. (1993): Analysis of shoulder positions and injury risk

exercises_to_avoid.reason: Internal rotation with abduction creates impingement at 70-120° arc
exercises_to_avoid.research: Blackburn et al. (1990): EMG analysis of shoulder exercises

exercises_to_avoid.reason: Excessive horizontal abduction strains anterior capsule
exercises_to_avoid.research: Fees et al. (1998): Upper extremity weight training modifications for the injured athlete

exercise_substitutions.rationale: Allows natural scapular rhythm while avoiding impingement position
exercise_substitutions.research: Kibler & McMullen (2003): Scapular dyskinesis and shoulder injury

exercise_substitutions.rationale: Maintains lat activation while protecting shoulder capsule
exercise_substitutions.research: Signorile et al. (2002): Shoulder muscle activation during pulldown exercises

phase_3_advanced.criteria: Full ROM and strength without pain

clinical_tests: Neer impingement sign (90° forward flexion + internal rotation)

protocols.clinical_evidence: Most common injury in running sports, 12-16% of all athletic injuries
risk_factors: Previous hamstring injury increases risk 2-6 fold
Hamstring:quadriceps strength ratio <60% increases injury risk
Age >25 years doubles injury risk in athletes

exercises_to_avoid_acute_phase.reason: May disrupt healing tissue in first 72 hours
exercises_to_avoid_acute_phase.research: Sherry & Best (2004): Comparison of hamstring rehabilitation programs

exercises_to_avoid_acute_phase.reason: Forces >6 times body weight before tissue can handle load
exercises_to_avoid_acute_phase.research: Verrall et al. (2001): Clinical risk factors for hamstring muscle strain injury

acute_phase_0_3_days.protocol: POLICE protocol (Protect, Optimal Loading, Ice, Compress, Elevate)
acute_phase_0_3_days.research: Bleakley et al. (2012): POLICE vs RICE protocol effectiveness

subacute_phase_4_14_days.progression: Nordic hamstring eccentrics when pain allows
subacute_phase_4_14_days.research: Askling et al. (2013): Acute hamstring injuries - exercise protocols

return_to_sport_phase.research: Sherry & Best (2004): Progressive agility vs stretching protocols

nordic_hamstring_exercise.research: Al Attar et al. (2017): Systematic review of injury prevention

strength_ratio_maintenance.research: Croisier et al. (2008): Strength imbalances and injury risk

outcome_data.time_to_return: Grade I: 2-3 weeks, Grade II: 4-6 weeks, Grade III: 8-12 weeks
